content:
You know that feeling when you're staring at a blank page, knowing you need to write something important but having no idea where to start? I've been there more times than I can count.

What I've learned is that the blank page isn't really the problem. The problem is trying to write something perfect on the first try. Once I gave myself permission to write badly first, everything changed.

Think about it this way: when you're talking to a friend about something you care about, do you carefully craft every sentence? Of course not. You just start talking, and somehow the right words come out.

Writing can work the same way. Instead of trying to impress an imaginary critic, I started writing as if I was explaining something to someone I actually know. Someone who's smart but doesn't have the same background I do.

The shift was immediate. Suddenly I wasn't worried about sounding sophisticated or using the right jargon. I was focused on being clear and helpful. And wouldn't you know it, that's exactly what makes writing actually connect with people.

So here's my challenge for you: next time you sit down to write, picture someone specific you're writing for. Not an abstract audience, but a real person with real questions. See if that changes how the words come out.
